Works

Orion

This three.js experiment is a collaboration with my good friend Thibaut, who initally wrote this very cool shader. He handed it off to me, I polished it then built a generative application around it.

It uses my text-seeded PRNG utility (see next project), allowing to save and share random outcomes simply by bookmarking the URL.

I really loved working on the generative side of things, so I'll probably do more of that in the future.

Vesuna

Generative applications are a lot of fun. However, when there is a wide range of possible outcomes, it can become very tedious to save, restore and share them.

To solve this issue, I wrote this tiny text-based random seed utility, built around Johannes Baagøe's Alea PRNG. It generates pseudorandom number sequences based on words, making it very easy to save/load precise results via hashtags.

Disintegrator

Brainstorming for an upcoming project, I envisioned elements exploding. So I made this lab to try my hand at that.

After several attempts, I ended up using tesselation, custom buffer attributes, and a mix of basic random + simplex noise. It also layers duplicates of the geometries, in order to counteract their inherent hollowness.

It is still raw and optimizable, but the visual result is pretty close to what I wanted.

Textformer

I love randomness, and I love experimenting with type. This logically led to this small javascript utility, that aims to build easy text animations based on random character changes.

I wanted it to be usable on its own, so I ended up writing and including a barebones animation system. It was probably overkill, because it works even better with tweening engines such as gsap or anime.js.

About
